IPRATROPIUM BROMIDE

ANTIMUSCARINICS (INHALED)

  • Indications and doses
  • Pregnancy
  • Side effects
  • Administration
  • Patient and carer advice
  • Cautions
  • Medicinal forms

Indications and doses

Reversible airways obstruction,

By inhalation of aerosol

  • For children 1 month–5 years
    20 micrograms 3 times a day.
  • For children 6–11 years
    20–40 micrograms 3 times a day.
  • For children 12–17 years
    20–40 micrograms 3–4 times a day.

Reversible airways obstruction, particularly in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease,

By inhalation of nebulised solution

  • For adults
    20–40 micrograms 3–4 times a day.
  • For adults
    250–500 micrograms 3–4 times a day.

Acute bronchospasm,

By inhalation of nebulised solution

  • For adults
    500 micrograms as required.
  • For children 1 month–4 years
    125–250 micrograms as required; maximum 1 mg per day.
  • For children 6–11 years
    250 micrograms as required; maximum 1 mg per day.
  • For children 12–17 years
    500 micrograms as required.

Severe or life-threatening acute asthma,

By inhalation of nebulised solution

  • For adults
    500 micrograms every 4–6 hours as required.
  • For children 1 month–11 years
    250 micrograms every 20–30 minutes for the first 2 hours, then 250 micrograms every 4–6 hours as required.
  • For children 12–17 years
    500 micrograms every 4–6 hours as required.

Rhinorrhoea associated with allergic and non-allergic rhinitis,

By intranasal administration

  • For adults
    2 sprays 2–3 times a day, dose to be sprayed into each nostril.
  • For children 12–17 years
    2 sprays 2–3 times a day, dose to be sprayed into each nostril.

Dose equivalence and conversion

1 metered spray of nasal spray = 21 micrograms.

Pharmacokinetics

The maximal effect of inhaled ipratropium occurs 30–60 minutes after use; its duration of action is 3 to 6 hours and bronchodilation can usually be maintained with treatment 3 times a day.

Advice when patient is pregnant

When used by inhalation

Inhaled drugs for asthma can be taken as normal during pregnancy.

Known side effects

Specific side effects

commonOrVeryCommon: dizziness, nausea in children, epistaxis, nasal dryness, nasal irritation,

uncommon: laryngospasm, pharyngeal oedema in children, pruritus, stomatitis, vomiting, headache, nausea, pharyngitis in children,

rare: atrial fibrilation in children, ocular accomodation disorder in children,

veryRare: gastro-intestinal motility disturbances, palpitations, urinary retention,

Directions for administration

When used by inhalation in adults

If dilution of ipratropium bromide nebuliser solution is necessary use only sterile sodium chloride 0.9%.

Advice for patients and carers

When used by inhalation

Advise patient not to exceed prescribed dose and to follow manufacturer’s directions.

Cautions regarding administration

  • When used by inhalation: cystic fibrosis
  • With intranasal use: avoid spraying near eyes
  • With intranasal use: bladder outflow obstruction
  • With intranasal use: cystic fibrosis
  • With intranasal use: prostatic hyperplasia in adults
  • With intranasal use: risk of glaucoma in children
  • With intranasal use: susceptability to angle-closure glaucoma in adults
  • When used by inhalation:

    Acute angle-closure glaucoma has been reported with nebulised ipratropium, particularly when given with nebulised salbutamol (and possibly other beta2 agonists); care needed to protect the patient's eyes from nebulised drug or from drug powder.

Prepared medicinal forms of IPRATROPIUM BROMIDE

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Pressurised inhalation
Nebuliser liquid
Spray
